content.description: SDS match on the lowest part of the sloper rail. Climb out of the cave via edge and slopers (Green block to the right is off) Go Straight up face to top out
content.location: Located on the satellite boulder in the cave just right of "Getting the Groove" This route is basically "Big Gulp" with the addition of starting in the cave

content.description: SDS on the left facing flake that connects into the rail that runs across the extent of the wall. Go left to right, finishing around the corner on the good juggy footholds.

This problem is listed as a project in the Dr. Topo Guide.  Climbs the Arete from a sit start and cool moves to a good high pocket. The last eight feet is easier climbing on pockets and jugs past the old pin.  An excellent highball.
Sit Start on the obvious hand holds at the far right of the Satellite Boulder.  Crank up and left to the first vertical crack system, mantle up and top out.
content.protection: pad and spotter, or several pads
content.location: Far right of the Satellite Boulder

content.description: 2 moves on sharp holds.  Stand start with your left fingers in a triangular pocket.  You may need a magnifying glass to find the footholds.  Do a powerful move up to the lip, and top it out.
content.protection: Pad & spotter to keep you off the tree
content.location: In the Sanctuary area. Just past old tree boulder & Gassed, on your right.

content.description: A must do for Second Mountain. Better problem than the name would suggest. Low start under roof climbs through sloper and mail slot to a big move to a crimp out to the lip.

Stand start from jugs; bring feet up and grab a strange finger-lock in the roof crack.  Squeeze hard on that lock and make a core-intensive move to work your other hand out the crack.  Follow the roof crack to the lip. Very unique boulder problem
content.location: This is on the Satellite boulder, about 20 feet left of the Roof-problem.

content.description: Do Slap Happy, then keep going past the mantle point to about halfway across the lip of the boulder, mantle and top out.  Top out is usually somewhat dirty.
content.protection: Your going to want several pads and spotters to move them and watch you.
content.location: Same start as Slap happy on Satellite boulder, just a longer version of the climb.

content.description: An excellent problem that's not in the guide book. Starts on same hold as The Nose climbs out the roof left via under cling and compression moves, up the orange face on the left side of the boulder. Very unique for Second.
Start the same as Ginger Snap, but instead of crossing over and topping out over the Sloper Problem continue up through slopers and pinches toping out on high face

This route was listed as unclimbed on climbing.com so I went up and found it a bit crimpier than a v0.  

  Start on the far side of the satellite boulder, past the roof to the left. Start matched in a pocket (it is usually spray painted green) and make your way up to some small crimps and get a high right foot. from there you can probably reach the top out jugs.
content.protection: none needed, Though you may see an old pin here or there. The walk down is safe also.
content.location: This is on the left most side of the Satellite boulder, which is the first boulder you see on your right after hiking u the fire trail. It has an obvious overhang you can not miss.

content.description: This one-mover is actually pretty good.  Grab a left-facing side pull & pinch feature. Figure out how to paste your feet and get your butt off the ground.  Make a powerful move up to a good edge.  Dirty, but engaging top-out.
content.location: Uphill, 5-10 minute walk from Satellite boulder. Pass the Old tree boulder, to the Slope-Back boulder.  Once you get to the Sanctuary, turn left and look back and you'll see gassed

content.description: Stand start on Jugs right of Tedium climb up through eyebrow features to good in cut edge.  Finish the same as Tedium.

A few friends and I thought this was the route for Big Gulp, but it seems to be a new route. Its a really fun combination of Big Gulp and the top of Worm World! Start on the jug for Big gulp, move straight up to the seam, move right and up toward the small crimps on worm world. Top out anyway you can!  (if anyone knows if this is already a climb, just holler.)
Start as for W.W. and Turn the earth. Climb the Jared crux in reverse and exit through the crack.
content.location: This problem starts on the left end of the satellite boulder.

content.description: Picturesque rightward traverse on the Bird boulder.  The best climb in the area.  2 Cruxes; first is matching after a weird, shouldery slap right from a crossed position.  Second crux is a toss from slopers to tiny hidden edges around the roof.
content.protection: At least 2 pads.  3-4 would be better.  This traverses over sharp, blocky talus.
content.location: Walk for a few hundred feet uphill from the Satellite boulder. Pass Melissa's boulder, Terminator boulder, the Finger, and the Pedestal boulder.  Look for the unmistakeable Bird feature on an overhanging, flat boulder on your right.

content.description: Start on Ginger Snap and Gain the Corner of Air Time.
SDS on the jug at the left of the Worm World cave. Go up to a horizontal seam and set up for a big move to another seam, and then go right to join the twin edges of Worm World and top out.
Same moves up to the seam as Big Gulp. Climbs straight up on tiny crimps with great feet. Avoid using jug on high right seam - shouldn’t change the grade regardless.

A set of incredible boulders on top of a scenic knob just off Rte 33 W, about 15 miles W of Harrisonburg in Rawley Springs.  Some hunter and ATV traffic, seasonally, but a beauty location especially in the late summer and fall.
